questions.text: At what gestational age, the level of amniotic fluid reaches its peak?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid volume is related to gestational age.

16w-200ml

Maximum amount of amniotic fluid seen at 32-34weeeks(1lit)

40w-800ml

>42w-200ml.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: All of the following may lead to polyhydramnios, except:
questions.solution:
It is a condition characterized by the presence of nodular projections on the amniotic membrane and is more associated with oligohydramnios or other abnormalities rather than an increase in amniotic fluid.

OPTION a. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula: This condition can lead to polyhydramnios because the fetus may not be able to properly swallow amniotic fluid, causing an accumulation.

OPTION b. Diabetes mellitus: Maternal diabetes is a well-known cause of polyhydramnios, as it can lead to increased fetal urine production and overall fluid accumulation.

OPTION c. Anencephaly: Anencephaly can result in polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing by the fetus, similar to the mechanism seen in tracheo-oesophageal fistula.

questions.text: Polyhydramnios can be diagnosed by all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
While a single deepest pocket of >2 cm is generally considered normal, a measurement of >5 cm is not sufficient to diagnose polyhydramnios. This value is too low to indicate excess amniotic fluid.

  1. Liquor volume > 2000 ml: This is a criterion for diagnosing polyhydramnios. Normal amniotic fluid volume is generally considered to be between 800 ml and 1000 ml, so >2000 ml indicates polyhydramnios.
  2. Single Deepest Pocket > 8 cm: This measurement is also used to diagnose polyhydramnios. A single deepest pocket (SDP) of >8 cm is a common criterion.
  3. AFI > 25 cm: The Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) of >25 cm is indeed indicative of polyhydramnios.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Hydramnios may be categorized on basis of AFI as:

  • mild if the AFI is 25 to 29.9 cm;
  • moderate, if 30 to 34.9 cm;
  • and severe, if >35 cm

Using a single deepest pocket of amnionic fluid, as is done in multifetal gestations:

  • mild hydramnios as 8 to 9.9 cm,
  • moderate as 10 to 11.9 cm,
  • severe hydramnios as >12 cm

questions.text: A 32 year old G5P1L0A3D1 woman visited an obstetrician at 18 weeks of gestation. She was asked to get an anomaly scan done, which showed the following sonographic sign. The liquor was scanty too. Which of the below mentioned syndromes is the prime cause of concern for the woman?
questions.solution:
The term "lying down adrenal sign" has been ascribed to the elongated appearance of the adrenal, not normally molded by the adjacent kidney, seen in Potter's syndrome.

Potter's Syndrome is bilateral renal agenesis exemplified by pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities, and typical facies. It is frequently associated with oligohydramnios.

a. Contradi syndrome:
This is not a commonly recognized syndrome associated with oligohydramnios or specific sonographic signs in pregnancy.

b. Moebius syndrome:
Moebius syndrome primarily affects cranial nerves and results in facial paralysis and other abnormalities, but it is not specifically linked to oligohydramnios or the described findings.

d. Denys-Drash syndrome:
This syndrome is associated with Wilms tumor and genital abnormalities, as well as renal dysplasia, but it is not primarily characterized by oligohydramnios or the specific sonographic findings typical of Potter's syndrome.

In summary, Potter's syndrome is the prime concern for the woman, given the scanty liquor and the context provided.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • If renal agenesis is bilateral, no urine is produced, and the resulting anhydramnios leads to pulmonary hypoplasia, limb contractures, and distinctive facies. When this combination results from renal agenesis, it is called Potter syndrome,
  • When these abnormalities result from severely decreased amnionic fluid volume from another etiology, such as bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney or autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, it is called Potter sequence.

Reference: Twinnings textbook of fetal abnormalities by Anne Marie Coady, Page 488

questions.text: All of the following can lead to oligohydramnios, except:
questions.solution:
Placental chorangioma is a benign tumor of the placenta that can sometimes lead to polyhydramnios due to increased blood flow and vascularity, rather than causing oligohydramnios.

OPTION a. Bilateral renal agenesis:
This condition leads to a complete absence of kidneys, resulting in a lack of urine production, which is a primary source of amniotic fluid. It is a common cause of oligohydramnios.

OPTION b. Bladder outlet obstruction:
This condition can lead to oligohydramnios because it prevents the fetus from urinating, thus reducing the amount of amniotic fluid produced.

OPTION c. Sirenomelia:
Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is associated with severe malformations, including renal agenesis, which can lead to oligohydramnios due to insufficient urine production.

OPTION d. Placental chorangioma:
Correct. In summary, placental chorangioma does not lead to oligohydramnios, making it the correct answer.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Selected renal abnormalities that lead to absent fetal urine production include

  • bilateral renal agenesis,
  • bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney, unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
  • infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.
  • fetal bladder outlet obstruction
  • Complex fetal genitourinary abnormalities such as persistent cloaca and sirenomelia similarly may result in a lack of amnionic fluid.

questions.text: The following drugs are notorious for causing oligohydramnios when administered to a pregnant female, except:
questions.solution:
Instead, it is often investigated for potential benefits in improving blood flow and may have positive effects on pregnancy outcomes.

OPTION A: ACE inhibitors:
These medications can lead to oligohydramnios, particularly when taken during the second and third trimesters, as they can affect renal function and fetal urine output.

OPTION B: Losartan:
As an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), losartan can also cause oligohydramnios by similar mechanisms as ACE inhibitors, especially when used in later pregnancy.

OPTION C: NSAIDs:
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can reduce renal blood flow and subsequently decrease fetal urine output, leading to oligohydramnios.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Oligohydramnios is also associated with exposure to drugs that block the renin-angiotensin system.

  • ACE inhibitors
  • ARBs
  • NSAIDs

choices.text: Specific gravity of Amniotic fluid is ~1.008 to 1.010
Osmolality of amniotic fluid at term is ~250 mosm/L
Amniotic fluid is completely replaced in 24 hours

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding characteristics of amniotic fluid:
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid is not completely replaced within 24 hours. While there is continuous turnover and absorption of amniotic fluid, it is not replaced in its entirety that quickly. The volume of amniotic fluid remains relatively stable throughout pregnancy.

Option a. Specific gravity of amniotic fluid is ~1.008 to 1.010:
This statement is correct. The specific gravity of amniotic fluid typically falls within this range.

Option b. Osmolality of amniotic fluid at term is ~250 mosm/L:
This is also correct. The osmolality of amniotic fluid is usually around 250 mosm/L at term.

Option d. It is faintly alkaline:
This statement is correct. Amniotic fluid is typically slightly alkaline, with a pH range of about 7.0 to 7.5.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 24 year old G1P0 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents for an antenatal check-up. She has no significant past medical history. A routine growth scan is performed. The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 14. What is the largest source of amniotic fluid at this gestational age?
questions.solution:
At 32 weeks of gestation, the largest source of amniotic fluid is primarily fetal urine (option A).

b. Maternal serum:
While maternal serum does play a role in the composition of amniotic fluid, it is not a significant source of fluid at this gestational age.

c. Secretion from amniotic epithelium:
This contributes to amniotic fluid but is a minor source compared to fetal urine.

d. Fetal lung secretions:
Fetal lung secretions contribute to amniotic fluid but are not the largest source.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Early in pregnancy, amnionic fluid arises as a transudate of plasma either from the fetus through its nonkeratinized skin or from the mother across the uterine decidua and placenta surface
  • Water transport across the fetal skin continues until keratinization occurs at 22 to 25 weeks.
  • In the second half of pregnancy, fetal urination is the primary source of amnionic fluid.
  • In late gestation, the fetal respiratory tract also produces approximately 350 mL of lung fluid per day.

questions.text: A 32 year old G1P0 presents to antenatal clinic at 28 weeks of gestation. Her SFH is more as compared to dates. A scan was done which shows an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 28 cm. A 20-week ultrasound done earlier showed normal fetal anatomy and AFI. What is the best next step in this scenario?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild polyhydramnios and a normal fetal anatomical screen. The best next step in evaluation is maternal diabetes screening because diabetes is the most common cause of mild polyhydramnios.

Gestational diabetes is responsible for 8% to 25% of pregnancies with polyhydramnios. The most likely mechanism for this is fetal hyperglycemia, leading to excessive urination via osmotic diuresis.

OPTION a. Blood group (ABO & Rh typing):
While important, this is not the immediate next step in the context of increased amniotic fluid.

OPTION c. Amniocentesis:
This is typically done for genetic testing or to assess for infections or other conditions but is not the best next step in this situation.

OPTION d. Preeclampsia screening:
While preeclampsia is a concern in pregnancy, the primary issue here is the increased amniotic fluid, which is more directly related to gestational diabetes.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Diabetes is the most common cause of mild polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 28 year old multigravida presents at 30 weeks of gestation with polyhydramnios. She is put on indomethacin to decrease the amount of liquor. All of the following neonatal complications may arise due to prolonged use of indomethacin, except:
questions.solution:
Indomethacin is actually used to close a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in preterm infants rather than causing it. Thus, this is not a complication associated with indomethacin use.

OPTION b. Necrotizing enterocolitis:
This condition can occur in preterm infants, and there is some association with NSAID use during pregnancy, making this a potential complication.

OPTION c. Periventricular leukomalacia:
This condition, characterized by white matter damage in the brain, has been associated with preterm birth and potential vascular compromise, which could be influenced by maternal use of indomethacin.

OPTION d. Ileal perforation:
This is a rare but serious complication that can occur with prolonged use of indomethacin, as it may affect intestinal blood flow.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Patent ductus arteriosus is not a complication arising from the prolonged use of indomethacin; rather, indomethacin is used to treat PDA in neonates. Ibuprofen can also be used for closing of PDA.

Reference: Hwang DS, Mahdy H. Polyhydramnios. [Updated 2023 Feb 20]

questions.text: Identify this placental anomaly:
questions.solution:
PLACENTA SUCCENTURIATA: One (usual) or more small lobes of placenta, size of a cotyledon, may be placed at varying distances from the main placental margin. A leash of vessels connecting the main to the small lobe traverse through the membranes. The accessory lobe is developed from the activated villi on the chorionic laeve.

CIRCUMVALLATE PLACENTA: The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete. The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between.

PLACENTA MEMBRANACEA: The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Battledore placenta in which the cord anchors at the placental
  • In monochorionic twins, marginal insertion may be associated with weight discordance

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed to have single umbilical artery. Which of the following chromosomal anomalies is most commonly seen in association with this?
questions.solution:
• Single umbilical artery is present in about 1-2% of cases. It may be due to failure of development of one artery or due to its atrophy in later months.
  • It is more common in twins and in babies born of women with diabetes, epilepsy, oligohydramnios, hydramnios, preeclampsia and antepartum hemorrhage.
  • It is frequently associated with congenital malformation of the fetus (20-25%). Renal and genital anomalies, Trisomy 18 are common.
  • There is increased chance of abortion, fetal aneuploidy, prematurity, IUGR and increased perinatal mortality.

A single umbilical artery (SUA) is associated with various congenital anomalies and chromosomal abnormalities. Among the trisomies listed:

Option a. Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome):
While SUA can be associated with Trisomy 13, it is not as commonly linked as with Trisomy 18.

Option c. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome):
SUA can occur in infants with Trisomy 21, but it is not the most common association.

Option d. Trisomy 16:
This is usually not compatible with life and is not commonly identified in live-born infants.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • In an anomalous fetus,an SUA greatly increases the aneuploidy risk, and amniocentesis is recommended or karyotype assessment.
  • If Targeted sonography finds otherwise normal anatomy, an isolated SUA in an otherwise low-risk pregnancy does not significantly raise the fetal aneuploidy risk.

Trisomy 18 is the chromosomal anomaly most commonly associated with a single umbilical artery

choices.text: Delivery of oxygen to the fetus

questions.text: What is the function of Hofbaeur cells in placenta?
questions.solution:
Hofbauer cells, which are fetal macrophages, important mediators of immunoprotection at the maternal-fetal interface.

OPTIONWISE EXPLANATION:

Hofbauer cells are specialized macrophages found in the placenta. Their primary functions include:

a. Nourishment to the fetus:
While the placenta plays a crucial role in nourishing the fetus, Hofbauer cells are not directly responsible for this function.

c. Synthesis of placental hormones:
This is primarily the function of trophoblast cells, not Hofbauer cells.

d. Delivery of oxygen to the fetus:
Oxygen delivery is primarily facilitated by maternal blood flow through the placenta and fetal hemoglobin, not by Hofbauer cells.

In summary, Hofbauer cells are primarily involved in immunoprotection at the feto-maternal interface.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Hobauer cells are fetal macrophages.
  • These are round with vesicular, often eccentric nuclei and with very granular or vacuolated cytoplasm.
  • They grow in number and maturational state throughout pregnancy and appear to be important mediators of protection at the maternal-fetal inter-ace (Johnson, 2012).
  • These Macrophages are phagocytic, have an immunosuppressive phenotype, produce various cytokines, and provide paracrine regulation of trophoblast functions

choices.text: The number of muscle fibres decreases, but the myometrial cell size remains more or less the same
At the end of 6 weeks, its measurement is almost similar to that of the non-pregnant state and weighs about 60 g
The external os never reverts back to the nulliparous state

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the changes in uterus post-partum, except:
questions.solution:
After childbirth, the uterus undergoes several significant changes during the postpartum period, known as involution, where it returns to its non-pregnant state.

OPTION a. The number of muscle fibres decreases, but the myometrial cell size remains more or less the same:
Incorrect. The number of myometrial muscle fibers does not decrease; rather, the size of the myometrial cells reduces (atrophy), as the uterus contracts back to its pre-pregnancy size. There is no loss of muscle fibers themselves, only a reduction in cell size.

OPTION b. Endometrial regeneration starts by the 7th day:
Correct. The regeneration of the endometrial lining begins within the first week postpartum, usually starting by the 7th day.

OPTION c. At the end of 6 weeks, its measurement is almost similar to that of the non-pregnant state and weighs about 60 g:
Correct. By 6 weeks postpartum, the uterus typically returns to near its non-pregnant size, weighing approximately 60-80 grams.

OPTION d. The external os never reverts back to the nulliparous state:
Correct. After delivery, the external os becomes more slit-like and never reverts to the round, nulliparous state.

In summary, the incorrect statement is that the number of muscle fibers decreases while cell size remains the same, as the correct process involves reduction in myometrial cell size rather than a decrease in the number of fibers.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • The total number of myocytes does not decline appreciably-rather, their size decreases markedly.
  • Weights from removed uteri approximate 500g by 1 week postpartum, 300g by 2 weeks, and at 4 weeks involution is complete and the uterus weighs approximately 100 g (Williams, 1931).
  • Ater each successive delivery, the uterus is usually slightly larger than before the most recent pregnancy.

choices.text: Continue breast feeding from both the breasts
Immediately start antibiotics and breastfeed only when antibiotics are discontinued.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primiparous woman presents to the postnatal OPD complaining of pain in her left breast. The patient is postpartum day 12 from an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39+6 weeks. She reports no difficulty breast-feeding for the first several days postpartum, but states that for the past week her daughter has had difficulty latching on. Three days ago her right nipple became dry and cracked, and since yesterday it has become increasingly swollen and painful. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Her right nipple and areola are warm, swollen, red, and tender. There is no fluctuance or induration, and no pus can be expressed from the nipple.
What should be the correct advice she must be given?
questions.solution:
Suggests that the patient is having mastitis. Mastitis is not a contraindication for breast feeding. She should continue feeding from both the breasts.

It helps to empty the breast, reduce engorgement, and promote healing. It also helps to prevent further milk stasis, which can worsen the condition.

OPTIONWISE EXPLANATION

b. Breastfeed from unaffected breast only:
This option is not advisable as it can lead to increased pressure and potential complications in the affected breast.

c. Immediately start antibiotics and breastfeed only when antibiotics are discontinued:
While antibiotics may be necessary in cases of severe infection, breastfeeding should not be stopped. Most antibiotics are safe during breastfeeding.

d. Stop breastfeeding immediately:
This is not recommended as it can exacerbate the condition and lead to more complications.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Mastitis:

  • Risk factors include nursing difficulties,cracked nipples, and oral antibiotic therapy.
  • Infection almost invariably is unilateral, and marked engorgement usually precedes inflammation Symptoms include chills or actual rigors, which are soon followed by fever and tachycardia.
  • Pain is severe, and the breast(s) becomes hard and red. Approximately 10 percent of women with mastitis develop an abscess. Detection of fluctuation may be difficult, and sonography is usually diagnostic (Fig. 37-8).

Management:

  • Vigorous milk expression may be sufficient treatment alone.
  • Dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally four times daily, may be started empirically.
  • Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin sensitive.

questions.text: Main hormone responsible for galactokinesis:
questions.solution:
OPTIONWISE EXPLANATION

a. Estrogen:
Estrogen plays a role in breast development and preparation for lactation but is not primarily responsible for milk ejection.

b. Progesterone:
Progesterone is involved in the maintenance of pregnancy and also supports breast development but does not facilitate the ejection of milk.

c. Prolactin:
Prolactin is crucial for milk production (lactogenesis) but does not directly cause milk ejection.

d. Oxytocin:
Correct. Oxytocin is the hormone responsible for galactokinesis, which is the ejection of milk from the mammary glands during breastfeeding. It causes the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli to contract, facilitating the movement of milk through the ducts.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Prolactin for galactopoeisis.
  • Oxytocin is the main hormone responsible for galactokinesis.
  • Estrogen and Progestrone for mammogenesis

questions.text: Glucose, which is the principal source of energy, is transferred to the fetus by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Glucose which is the principal source of energy is transferred to the fetus by facilitated diffusion. Hence option b is correct
  • There are transporter proteins (GLUT-1) for facilitated diffusion.
  • GLUT-1 is located in syncytiotrophoblast.
  • Glucose transfer from mother to fetus is not linear. Transfer rates decrease as maternal glucose concentration increases.
  • Fetal glucose level is lower than that of the mother indicating rapid rate of fetal utilization of glucose.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

GLUT 1 is located in Placenta transport glucose via facilitated diffusion.

choices.text: The umbilical arteries do not possess an internal elastic lamina but have got well-developed muscular coat
Both the arteries and the vein do not possess vasa vasorum
The arteries are derived from the internal iliac arteries of the fetus
The right one disappears by the 4th month, leaving behind one artery which carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding umbilical arteries?
questions.solution:
Both umbilical arteries remain present throughout gestation, and they carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

OPTION a. The umbilical arteries do not possess an internal elastic lamina but have got well-developed muscular coat

OPTION b. Both the arteries and the vein do not possess vasa vasorum

OPTION c. The arteries are derived from the internal iliac arteries of the fetus

KEY TAKE AWAY:

There are 2 UA + 1UV in umbilical cord.

Umbilical arteries persist throughout gestation.

Single umbilical artery is associated with other congenital anomalies.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for lactation suppression?
questions.solution:
Option a, b & c are galactogogues or drugs which improve lactation.

Option d is correct as Cabergoline is used for lactation suppression.

  • Drugs to improve milk production (galactogogues): Metoclopramide (10 mg thrice daily) domperidone, Intranasal oxytocin contracts myoepithelial cells and causes milk let down.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Lactation is suppressed when the baby is born dead or dies in the neonatal period or if breastfeeding is contraindicated.
  • Cabergoline, a D2 agonist acts by stimulating dopamine receptors.

questions.text: The most common organism responsible for puerperal genital infection:
questions.solution:
Mostly puerperal infections are polymicrobial. Anaerobic streptococci like peptostreptococcus seems to be the commonest of these, hence option d is correct.

Puerperal infections are bacterial infections of the genital tract that occur after giving birth. They can be caused by a number of bacteria, including:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus)
  • Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus)
  • Escherichia coli (E. coli)
  • Staphylococcus spp.
  • Clostridium welchii
  • Chlamydia
  • Gonococci

Other risk factors for puerperal infections include:

  • Diabetes
  • Liver disease
  • Malignancy
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Cesarean section
  • Inherited thrombophilia
  • Older age
  • Unhygienic delivery conditions

The risk of infection varies depending on the delivery method:

  • Standard vaginal delivery: 1-3% risk of infection
  • Scheduled cesarean delivery: 5-15% risk of infection
  • Non-scheduled cesarean delivery: 15-20% risk of infection

Puerperal infections can lead to serious complications, including:

Peritonitis, pelvic thrombophlebitis, pulmonary embolism, sepsis, septic shock, and pelvic abscess. Prompt diagnosis and treatment of postpartum fever can help prevent these complications.

OPTION a. Beta haemolytic streptococci:
While this can cause infections, it is not the most common organism associated with puerperal infections.

OPTION b. Clostridium difficile:
This organism is primarily associated with antibiotic-associated diarrhea and colitis, not specifically puerperal infections.

OPTION c. Escherichia coli:
E. coli can be involved in postpartum infections, especially urinary tract infections, but it is not the most common organism overall.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Peptostreptococcus is a part of the normal flora and is commonly associated with polymicrobial infections, making it a frequent organism involved in puerperal infections.
